pageContent:
Evidence for Bee decline, and 
overview of bee stressors 
By 
the end of this lecture, you should be able to: 
Describe the evidence for decline in honey bee and wild bee populations 
Recognize 
the difference between CCD and bee decline 
List 
the 5 main bee stressors and understand how a stress threshold can 
be reached 
Compare 
and contrast bee stressors for honey bees and wild bees 
Explain 
why pollination of California almonds is detrimental to honey bees 
Articulate 
the reasons why habitat loss/fragmentation, and climate 
change, are bee stressors

Part 1
-
Is there really a decline of 
honey bee populations?

Number of beehives in the world

colonies (in millions) (A) worldwide 
and (B) divided by geographical region from 1961 to 2018 (

)

The number of managed 
honey bee 
colonies in the US 
has been steady or increasing  in the last 25 years

Part 2
-
Decline of populations of wild bee species

Changes in distribution range for the rusty patched bumble bee in the USA (
Bombus 
affinis
) 
Draw the 
Extent of Occurrence (EEO) 
for each decade on the maps above. 
To  visualize  EOO,  draw  the  smallest 
possible 
convex
 
polygon around all rusty patched bumblebee observations in each decade. See below for an 
example of a convex vs. concave polygon.

a.
How has the estimated range and EOO of rusty patched 
bumblebees changed over time? 
b.
What does this tell us about this species’ extinction risk? 
Is it in decline? 
c. 
Write at least two hypotheses to explain why we see this 
pattern 
d.
Describe what other information you would need to know 
to test your hypothesis.

On January 10, 2017, the 
United States Fish and Wildlife 
Service 
placed 
B. 
affinis 
on the list of 
endangered 
species
, making the rusty patched bumble bee the first 
bee to be added to the list in the continental United 
States
[6
]
 
(seven species of 
yellow
-
faced bees 
native to 
the Hawaiian islands were added in 2016).

What about other wild bees in the US? 
Cameron 
et al
. 
, 2011. 
https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1014743108

• 
25% of North America 
bumble bees are in a 
threatened 
or near 
threatened category 
• 
Four bumble bee species 
are considered critically 
endangered 
B. 
affinis 
(rusty patched bumble bee) 
B.
 occidentalis 
B. 
pensylvanicus 
B. 
terricola

Why does it matter that 
some bumblebees are 
endangered and on the 
brink of extinction?

Share your ideas with your neighbors 
(DO NOT google it!) 
-
Be ready to share with the whole classroom 
using 
Polleverywhere

Powney 
et al. (2019) examined the change in the geographic 
ranges of 214 bee and 139 hoverfly species between 1980 and 
2012 
Powney 
et al. 2019

Analyzed bee and wasp extinction events 
from 1850
-
2014 
Ollerton et al. 2014

Analyzed bee decline (1900
-
2016)  around the world based on a massive dataset of 
over 
9 million specimen records
. Records included both pinned insects in 
entomological collections as well as visual observations (photos) available via 
iNaturalist [https://www.inaturalist.org/], and other citizen science platforms. 
Data 
spanned 1900 to 2016. 
Zattara 
& Aizen 2021

A lot of people in the world are focusing on 
saving the wrong bees!

Part 3
-
What are the main stressors of bee populations, 
whether 
honey bees 
or wild bees

Why are some bees doing poorly? 
Insecticides 
Fungicides 
Herbicides 
Lecture 
Nov 15 
Agrochemicals

Lectures Nov 1, 13 
Especially novel pests 
and pathogens 
Invasive 
species, Pests 
& Pathogens 
Agrochemicals

Invasive 
species, Pests 
& Pathogens 
Agrochemicals 
Climate Change 
• 
Range distribution 
• 
Phenological 
mismatch 
• 
Extreme events

Direct impact of 
large 
scale 
extreme weather 
events that are predicted 
to become more frequent 
15% of all US 
honey bees 
were in areas affected by Hurricane Ian in Florida (Fall 2022). 
That hurricane decimated countless bee colonies and starved the ones who survived

Phenological mismatch between plants and bees
Earlier snowmelt in Northern Japan led to flowering of a spring 
ephemeral (
Corydalis 
ambigua
) BEFORE its pollinator (bumblebees) 
emerged from its overwintering shelter 
https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/10.1098/rspb.2019.0573

Restriction of range distribution 
to cooler parts of the world 
Example 1:  the ranges of some bumblebees have begun to shift in response to climate with 
European bumblebees tending to disappear from the southern edges of their range 
https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.1255957

Example 2: 
future climate change impacts on North American bumblebee distributions were 
predicted using the most recent global change models 
C. 
Sirois
-
Delisle & J. T. 
Kerr. 
Sci. Rep
. 
8, 14464 
(2018).

Invasive 
species, Pests 
& Pathogens 
Agrochemicals 
Climate Change 
Habitat Change 
(loss and 
fragmentation) 
Low diversity (or lack of) 
resources and nest sites

Increasing fragmentation of habitats reduces levels of 
pollination, the diversity of pollinator species and 
numbers of individuals

Where cropland has increased, 
bee abundance has decreased

Relationship between the percent agricultural cover in the surrounding 
landscape at a 750
-
m radius and species richness in NY apple orchards 
Heather Grab et al. Science 2019;363:282
-
284

• 
removal native habitat by removing weeds and hedges 
• 
Reduction of plant types available because of large fields of 
monoculture, both spatially and temporally 
• 
Deforestation to make room for crops

IT IS Non intuitive, but forests, and that can be a hedge, provide valuable 
resources to hundreds of bee species, to the point that pollination and deforestation 
plus fragmentation of those forests has negatively impacted many wild bees

Why are some bees doing poorly? 
Invasive 
species, Pests 
& Pathogens 
Agrochemicals 
Climate Change 
Habitat Change 
(loss and 
fragmentation) 
Management 
Practices 
Stress of transport and poor 
management by some 
beekeepers

Beekeeping 
management practices can affect bee health and survival 
• 
take too much honey and give them sugary water instead 
• 
not keep track of pests and pathogens and let those populations increase 
• 
keep hives in close proximity to each other 
• 
not protect them enough in the winter 
• 
etc.

Mass transport of honey bees 
by migratory beekeepers 
Photo: 
apishive.com

What are some of the 
detrimental effects of 
migratory beekeeping 
on the bees 
themselves
? 
-
Share your ideas with your neighbors 
(DO NOT google it!) 
-
Be ready to share with the whole classroom 
using 
PollEverywhere 
3 min

The transport to California 
every February is 
particularly stressful 
» 
Transport across the US creates stress 
conditions (oxidative stress level increases,
Simone
-
Fistrom 
2016). 
» 
Yearly (must be active in February) and daily 
(moved across time zones) rhythms are 
disrupted (no data published)

» 
Foragers collect ONE type 
of pollen for a few weeks,
yet the brood needs a 
VARIETY of pollen types 
» 
Promotes national spread
of parasites and and 
diseases (esp. new ones!) 
» 
Many Fungicides are 
applied to almond trees 
DURING Pollination by
honey bees 
Varroa destructor 
Nosema 
cerana
